indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: The total installed SWH capacity and annual sale.

baseline.comment: 33,000 m2 of installed collector area in 2005 with 7,000 m2 of new SWH capacity installed in 2005 with the expected 5% annual growth.

target.comment: The adoption of the recommended legal and regulatory changes to promote sustainable SWH market development. Materials for public awareness raising as well as for training of building designers developed and/or adapted into Albanian conditions and made available in printed and electronic format. Enhanced awareness of the key financial sector stakeholder and local suppliers on the specific characteristics and financing opportunities in the SWH market. A certification and quality control scheme applicable for Albanian conditions and enhanced capacity of the supply chain to offer products and services promoting sustainable SWH market. The reporting framework and arrangement for the SWH market monitoring established.

actual.comment: At the end of June, 2015 the cumulative SWH systems area is 164,870 m2, with 20,305 m2 new installed area within the reporting period; The draft National Action Plan on Renewable Energy is revised and finalized, to reflect for the latest changes in the energy legal frame like the new law on Power Sector, new law on Concessions, etc., but also the successful government reform, preventing electricity non-payment (from 45% for the year 2013 to 32% for half 2015), removing one of the key obstacles for introduction of RES in Albanian Energy System. Upon request of MEI, Law on RES is provided with amended articles, affecting the most the RES-E and the feed-in tariffs, while the solar chapter has remained unchanged; The following sub-legal acts are prepared/discused: (i) Governmental Decree on the approval of the RES target in the final energy consumption and the NREAP associated with the statement of legislative purpose for its approval; ii) Governmental Decree for the approval of rules for mandatory installation of solar water heating systems in buildings and iii) Governmental Decree on exemption from value added tax and custom duties of solar water heating systems; The grounds are prepared for establishment of RES/EE Fund: revised laws on EE and RES and draft law on Energy Performance in Buildings provide for the Fund by the end of 2015; The NAMA mechanism is explored in line with findings of two prepared NAMAs in the areas of EE in buildings (including SWH) and fuel switch in cement sector; Another partnership is under implementation with the National Housing Agency to deploy EE measures (solar included) in the social buildings; The municipalities of Tirana, Elbasan, Shkoder, Sarande, Orikum, Gramsh and Fier are supported with technical assistance and demonstration projects to justify the solar obligation’s ordinances; A whole monitoring system is installed and processed data will get published in cooperation with Global Knowledge Management/UNEP; 712 participants (A

target.comment: The adoption of the recommended legal and regulatory changes to promote sustainable SWH market development. Materials for public awareness raising as well as for training of building designers developed and/or adapted into Albanian conditions and made available in printed and electronic format. Enhanced awareness of the key financial sector stakeholder and local suppliers on the specific characteristics and financing opportunities in the SWH market. A certification and quality control scheme applicable for Albanian conditions and enhanced capacity of the supply chain to offer products and services promoting sustainable SWH market. The reporting framework and arrangement for the SWH market monitoring established.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: (a) The extent to which evidence and consultations with all relevant stakeholders contribute to the development of locally owned strategic development plans for the counties of Shkodra and Vlora. (b) No. of activities initiated in Vlora and Shkodra which address priorities identified during the strategic planning process. (c) No. of local SMEs LEDAs provide with integrated services addressing their financing, production and marketing needs. (d) Degree to which the debate on sustainable local development in Albania contributes to and draws on international best practice.

baseline.comment:
(a1) Limited support for the territorial approach to development. (a2) No strategic integrated development plans in place for Vlora or Shkodra. (a3) Limited capacities and resources of regional and central government structures to design and implement strategic development plans at county level.
(b) Limited efforts to improve and valorise the endogenous development potential of Vlora and Shkodra.
(c1) Limited capacities of small business enterprises to compile business plans and be able to attract investments and make use of bank loans. (c2) Lack of functional chains of value for endogenous products resulting in difficulties to reach domestic and international markets and establish recognized brands. (c3) Limited capacities of local economic development agencies (LEDAs) to offer integrated services to existing small and medium enterprises and the start-up of new ones.
(d) Limited capacities of Albanian universities and other research institutes to conduct and implement research and research-oriented action on recognizing innovative local practices in economic and human development.

target.comment:
(a13) The cooperation and collaboration between local stakeholders (CPCs, LGUs, LEDAs), UNDP and other development actors is strengthened in the implementation of regional strategic priorities
(b8) A proposal on the inclusion of disadvantaged people in economy / labour market is drafted and submitted for funding
(b9) The two priority interventions co-funded by the Italian decentralized cooperation members (Friuli-Venezia Giulia region) i.e. the Hotel Villages model and “Marubi Visual Museum” are being implemented successfully

actual.comment:
Result (a13) is achieved. The regions of Shkoder and Vlora, through their own administrations as well as through TEULEDa and AULEDA, are using the Regional Strategic Plans to build new partnerships and reach agreements of cooperation with UNDP and other local and international development partners.
Result (b8) is achieved. A joint proposal between the municipality of Saranda (part of Vlora region) and Decentralised Cooperation partners from Italy (Region of Apulia and Province of Lecce) was developed and submitted for donor funding. The proposal intended inclusion of disadvantaged people in the local and regional labour market. UNDP ART GOLD 2 coordinated the whole process.
Result (b9) is achieved. Both priority interventions co-funded by the Italian decentralized cooperation members (Friuli-Venezia Giulia region) i.e. the Hotel Villages model and “Marubi Visual Museum” are being implemented successfully.

target.comment:
(b10) The two initiatives implemented in cooperation with Friuli-Venezia Giulia region, i.e. Hotel Villages promoting mountainous tourism and “Marubi Visual Museum”, are successfully completed
(c5) Cooperation with and support to LEDAs is strengthened through joint involvement in local, national and international projects of cooperation

actual.comment:
Target (b10) has been achieved. The Hotel Villages has been implemented through the traditional restoration and tourist friendly improvement of six guesthouses of traditional architecture in the Albanian Alps and training of 25 local residents in tourism operation and foreign languages. The “Marubi Visual Museum” has launched its public website for retrieving photos from its archives and along the year over 100 thousand negatives have been catalogued and digitized and the process will expand in 2016.
Re target (c5) UNDP continued to support AULEDA in Vlora and TEULEDA in Shkoder through engaging them in project activities related to local development and promoting their networking and partnership; for instance AULEDA was supported to participate and share its local experience with an international audience in the Third World Forum on Local Economic Development held in Turin in October 2015.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Strategic Plan for Albania’s Marine and Coastal Protected Areas 2. Two proposals for new MPA establishment 3. Legal environment for MCPA management 4. Adequate management of buffer zone for MPA 5. Guideline for adequate management of buffer zone for MCPA 6. Management Boards at MCPAs 7. # of agreements or memorandum of cooperation/ understanding MPA/PA issues 8. Management effectiveness tools for MCPAs 9. Number of manuals/ guidebooks prepared as a resource for imparting further training 10. Funding of Karaburuni-Sazani MPA 11. Status of the seagrass Posidonia oceanica along Karaburuni and Albanian Ionian coast

baseline.comment: No Strategy for Marine Protected Areas No Management Board at MPA No Management Effectiveness tool for MCPAs in place

target.comment: 1. Assistance on filling the legal gals in MCPA conservation and management framework in respect to EU approximation process 2. Dissemination of information to the protected areas administration and other partners/ stakeholders through different dedicated publications, public hearings and presentations with stakeholders groups, website uploads materials etc. 3. Produce a video documentary on marine biodiversity and associated values 4. Multidisciplinary expertise (geo-botanist, marine biologistetc) for assessment and preparation of the justification for a new MPAs 5. Produce a guide on buffers zones along the MCPA 6. Assist MPA Administration in enforcement and control mechanism through MoUs arrangement with local institutions and equipment /tools 7. Developing curriculas for training on MPA management following an ‘in-depth Training Needs Assessment’ 8. Study visit in Croatian MCPA for exchanging of experiences and management practices 9. Inspecting law enforcement monitoring trips

actual.comment: 1. Legal analyses in MCPA conservation and management framework in respect to EU approximation process completed 2. Information to the protected areas administration and other partners/ stakeholders through different dedicated publications, public hearings and presentations with stakeholders groups, website uploads materials etc. dissemination ed 3. A video documentary on marine biodiversity and associated values produced 4. A guide on buffers zones along the MCPA is prepared. 5. MPA Administration is being assisted and MoUs with local institutions is under implementation 6. Study visit in Croatian MCPA for exchanging of experiences is conducted

target.comment: 1. Public hearing and participatory process for the approval of the Management Plan for Karaburun-Sazani 2. Implementing priority management actions according to the Management Plan for Karaburun-Sazani 3. Production of the Business Plan for Karaburun-Sazani 4. Assist MPA Administration in enforcement and control mechanism through Micro Capital Agreement arrangement with local institutions and NAPA 5. Strengthening of the MPA administration with training and equipment 6. Assistance of the MoE for the new MPA designation, Porto Palermo 7. Produce a booklet with information on MCAPs 8. Produce of the Manual of Training of Trainers on MCPAs management 9. Training on management effectiveness and produce an online tracking tool on management effectiveness 10. Production of the photo album on Karaburun-Sazani MPA

actual.comment: 1. Public hearing and participatory process for the approval of the Management Plan for Karaburun-Sazani is completed. 2. Micro Capital Agreement arrangements with local institutions and NAPA are signed to assist MPA Administration in enforcement 3. Equipment for MPA administration are provided. 4. Assistance of the MoE for the new MPA designation, Porto Palermo is provided. 5. Booklet with information on MCAPs is produced 6. Manual of Training of Trainers on MCPAs management is produced 7. Application online on tracking tool on management effectiveness is produced and provided.

result.title: Objective
result.description: To improve coverage and management effectiveness of Albaniaâ€™s marine and coastal protected areas.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Area under protection as Coastal and Marine Protected Areas

baseline.comment:
100,236 ha
(existing coastal protected areas - mainly coastal wetlands)

target.comment:
An additional 12,570.82 ha declared as Albaniaâ€™s first MPA (Karaburun Sazani)
An additional 3,500 ha in the process of being declared as MPAs (Rodoni Cape-Lalzi Bay and Pagane-Kepi i Stillos)

actual.comment: Two other MCPA, Porto Palermo (and Cape of Rodoni are in the process to be proclaimed. Public hearing are organizes and respective reporting are delivered. The draft Decision of Council of Ministers for Porto Palermo foresees the status Natural Park for a surface of 2,067.75 ha. It is planned to be proclaimed within 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Enabling environment created for revision of the existing MCPA status, facilitated by the project

baseline.comment: Weak capacities for revising MCPAs status

target.comment: At least 2 MoE experts capable for conducting revision of MCPA according the international standards.

actual.comment:
Training curricula and modules on marine biodiversity conservation and management are developed.
Training workshops have been organized involving more than 45 local specialists, MCPA administration, as well as 5 experts from the MoE.
A Manual on Training on Integrated Management of MCPAs is published.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Improvement in management effectiveness of Karaburuni-Sazani MPA measured through change in METT scores

baseline.comment: Baseline METT Score as percent of Total Possible Score is 17%

target.comment: Target is 45-55%

actual.comment:
METT assessment report accomplished on 16th December 2014 through e regional training workshop in Divjaka PA. METT assessment is accomplished for all coastal PAs
The score for MPA Karaburun-Sazani, increased from 39 to 45 attesting for the efforts made in enforcement and management of the site.
The project is developing a user friendly electronic format for METT (web based)

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Increased Systemic, Institutional and Individual capacities for establishing and managing an MCPA system

baseline.comment:
See UNDP Capacity Development Scorecard in Annex 5 for baseline
Systemic - 37%
Institutional - 29%
Individual - 38%

target.comment:
See UNDP Capacity Development Scorecard in Annex 5 for target
Systemic - 90%
Institutional - 87%
Individual - 95%

actual.comment:
Systematic 40%, 67%
Institutional 36% 58%
Individual 43% 57%
Compared with 2014, UNDP Capacity Development Scorecard for MCPA, shows an increase of 27% for systematic, 22% for institutional and 14% for individual level. There are development in legislation, strategies and programmes. A new institution is established, National Agency for Protected Areas, which shows the political will towards Protected Areas and will help on building consensus among all institutions and stakeholders, capacity to mobilize information and knowledge and capacity to monitor, evaluate, report and learn. Compared to the baseline there is an increase of about 30 %.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Improved bio-geographical representation of marine and coastal protected areas (MCPA)

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Strategic Plan for Albaniaâ€™s Marine and Coastal Protected Areas (SPMCPA)

baseline.comment: No Strategic Plan has been developed for this sub-system of the national PA system

target.comment: SPMCPA is developed and approved by the Inter-ministerial Council or the Council of Ministers

actual.comment: The updated “Biodiversity Strategy and Action Plan” is approved by the government and the SPMCPA is taken into consideration and incorporated in the document.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Legal Instrument establishing MPA at Karaburuni-Sazani (12,570.82 ha.)

baseline.comment: No Legal Instrument

target.comment: Legal Instrument is approved by the Council of Ministers

actual.comment:
The law on biodiversity is revised.
A new law on PA is under development, accomplishing a combined review of all legal acts pertinent to environment conservation and management, possible models/ mechanisms for MCPA administration, revenues mechanisms, changes with establishment of NAPA – National Agency for Protected Areas as the biggest institutional development taking over the management of PA with direct dependence from the Minster of Environment, splitting the management of protected areas form the forestry service structure

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Legal Instrument incorporates best practice in design of such an instrument and can serve as a model for declaration of future MPAs

baseline.comment: There are no MPAs in Albania and, therefore, no examples of a legal instrument establishing an MPA

target.comment: Legal Instrument for Karaburuni-Sazani MPA is developed as a model for future MPAs

actual.comment:
The roadmap is prepared for the MCPA legal frame and recommendations to improve legislation and approximate it with EU directive.
In additions the PA law is paying due attention on all latest institutional progress and development of relevant sector (tourism activities, zoning, enforcement, environmental inspectorates, fisheries inspectorates, the Coast Guard, etc.)

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Clearly demarcated buffer zones in Karaburuni-Sazani MPA, with specific guidance on permissible activities included in the Management Plan

baseline.comment: No buffer zones defined

target.comment: Buffer zones and permissible activities defined

actual.comment:
Assessment report on marine and coastal areas buffer zone is finalized, including guidelines/ recommendations on setting up buffer zones for MPAs.
The integrated management planning process (Karaburuni - Sazani) developed with significant participatory approach has considered the buffer zone.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Clearly demarcated buffer zones in existing 9 coastal PAs, with specific guidance on permissible activities for inclusion in the Management Plan

baseline.comment:
No buffer zones defined
No Management Plans in place.

target.comment: Buffer zones and permissible activities defined

actual.comment:
The management planning for the MPA Karaburun - Sazani and the buffer zoning roadmap are developed. Buffer zone protocols and rules are being provided as respective management arrangements.
In addition the management plan for Porto Palermo MPA has also developed the site zoning and site boundaries with due attention in the buffer area as well. The zoning process has started in the meantime for the Cape of Rodoni.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Process of identification of additional MPAs at Rodoni Cape-Lalzi Bay and Pagane-Kepi i Stillos has begun.

baseline.comment: Currently the adjacent areas have a protection status as CPAs only.

target.comment: Technical and scientific work for realizing designation of these areas is complete, and political consultation process has been initiated

actual.comment:
Processes for the designation of two additional MPAs: Porto Palermo and Cape of Rodoni are progressing well. According to the SPMCPA, the two priority areas to be proclaimed are Porto Palermo (not Pagan Kepi Stillos) and Rodoni Cape.
Ecologic evaluation, public hearing organized with MoE, relevant document for designating these sites, as well as meetings with local stakeholders, including informative materials and posters are accomplished.
The draft Decision of Council of Ministers for Porto Palermo foresees the status Natural Park for a surface of 2,067.75 ha. It is planned to be proclaimed within 2015.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Improved management arrangements for MCPAs based on clear institutional responsibilities and development of capacities

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Management Boards at MCPAs

target.comment: At least 2 MCPAs have Management Boards

actual.comment:
2 +
There is organized another MC meeting during reporting period (5th MC, 27 January 2015) focusing and discussing the site management plan, project progress, main problems and other progress (mainly management plan document and priority actions), as well as financial issues. The project plan for 2015 is discussed and approved at the Management Committee.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Inter-institutional agreements on management of marine and land-based threats to MCPAs

target.comment: At least 2 official agreements or memorandum of cooperation/ understanding between relevant ministries/institutions

actual.comment:
2 +
MoU are continuing to be implemented with the Municipality of Orikumi and Regional Agency of PA with focus collection data and info on illegal activities.
Monthly reports by Municipality of Orikum and Regional Agency of PA deliver to the Ministry of Environment.
MoU/ Micro capital Grant Agreement with an Albanian NGO (INCA) is in place for the implementation of priority actions in Karaburun-Sazani MPA as per management plan.
Cooperation and synergies include Prefecture of Vlora, Commune Center, Regional Directory of Environment of Vlora, Coastline National Agency, NGOs.
Synergies and logistic are ensured with National Agency for Protected Areas, NAPA (recently established, February 2015) for the protection and conservation of marine biodiversity.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Management effectiveness of existing 9 CPAs is being tracked

baseline.comment: Baseline METT Scores as percent of Total Possible Score to be estimated by the end of 2nd year

target.comment: Progress in METT scores assessed annually thereafter

actual.comment:
9 +
Regional training workshop on METT accomplished on 16th December 2014.
METT assessment results are:
PN Korab Korit. - 44%
Shebenik - 67%
NP Lure - 44%
NP LLogara –67%
Bize Martanesh -44%
NP Valbona - 67%
NP Tomorri - 67%
NP Kune Vaini 56%
Porto Palermo - 44%
NP Mali i Dajtit - 67%
NP Karavasta - 78%
Fushe Kuqe Ishem-67%
NP Hotove - 56%
The score for MPA Karaburun-Sazani, increased from 39 to 45 attesting for the efforts made in enforcement and management of the site.
The project is developing a user friendly electronic format for METT

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Number of manuals/ guidebooks prepared as a resource for imparting further training

baseline.comment: Very limited

target.comment: 6 training modules

actual.comment:
6 +
Training curricula and modules on marine biodiversity conservation and management are developed. A number of trainings and workshop has been organized during 2013-2014, involving more than 45 local specialists, MCPA administration, as well as 5 experts from the MoE. The final training workshop was held on August 2014
A Manual on Training on Integrated Management of MCPAs is published.
Other publications are on the way include buffer zone guideline, a passport for the Albanian MCPA, and a photo album for Karaburun-Sazani MPA values.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Gap between funding needs of Karaburuni-Sazani MPA and available funds

baseline.comment: Gap to be assessed by end of 1st year

target.comment: At least 50% of funding needs are being met.

actual.comment:
The priority actions taken from the MP document are duly addresses. A Micro Capital Grant Agreement is signed with INCA addressing the financial gap in funding priority management actions of the MCPA Karaburun-Sazani which will capture, design and establish the buoys system, repair and maintenance of some moles, drafting and implement the code of conduct for the observation of wildlife, updating inventory and monitoring of caves, assess the situation of underwater objects, fishing capacity assessment, awareness packages and tourist products, training, etc.
The Business Plan for MPA Karaburun-Sazani is under preparation.
The NAPA has meantime sustained the government efforts and is providing government funds for accomplishing management action and conservation measures at MCPA Karaburun-Sazani.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Increased understanding of the fish resources of the MPA

baseline.comment: Very limited studies on fish resources for the targeted area (s)

target.comment: At least 3 site diagnoses missions and reports for K-S MCPA, deep insights fishery cross-sectorial studies scoping the management and conservation of this sector

actual.comment:
3
There are three mission accomplished in cooperation with Conservatoire du Littoral assessing the habitats and species on the target area including fish populations.
The reports are delivered and taken into consideration for the Management Plan preparation of MPA Karaburun-Sazani.

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description: Aware inhabitants and stakeholders adjacent to the MPA (and countrywide) of MBD values

baseline.comment:
No means and tools available at local level to deliver information to stakeholders.
No media coverage and no website for the targeted site. Local media (radio and TV) has never run programme on MCPA and /or MBD values).

target.comment:
At least 3 dedicated programmes on MCPA and MBD conservation are mediatised per year.by EoY 5.
All school children in Orikumi and Vlora are fully aware of globally important biodiversity in the K-S MCPA by EoY 5.

actual.comment:
3 +
There have been produce a short documentary for the MPA site, and several public awareness activities (celebration of significand days such as 22nd May, 2nd February, 5 June, etc.) The Environment Film Festival has conducted its 3rd edition in Albania. The project has been actively part focusing on marine biodiversity films and involving the local schools.
Awareness campaign is being conducted as part of implementation of the Management Plan in Karaburun-Sazani MPA.
Knowledge and information is also produced and delivered in scope of new MPA designation processes (Porto Palermo and Cape of Rodoni through workshops and posters).

iati-activity.title: PIMS 4467 Albania Third National Communication to UNFCCC
iati-activity.description: PIMS 4467 CC EA Self-Assessment TNC Albania

iati-activity.title: ALBANIA Third National Communi
iati-activity.description: The objectives of the TNC are to enable Albania to enhance available GHG emission data, perform targeted research, and strengthen technical capacity and institutions to address GHG inventory, GHG mitigation and adaptation to climate change.

transaction.disbursement-channel: Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account

Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account
Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account
Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account
Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: (A) Publication of the TNC. (B) Building institutional capacity in Albania for education, training and public awareness related to climate change.

target.comment: to update the annual Albanian Inventory of Anthropogenic GHGs to the period 2000-2009, focusing on the sectors/gases that have a significant share of GHG emissions such as the transport sector; downscaled global models will be developed to regionalize climate projections and apply in Vulnerability and Adaptation assessments that are focused on the entire coastal region; state-of-the-art GHG mitigation modeling frameworks will be used to developed a national low carbon development strategy. Albania’s description of national circumstances will be updated, as well as the steps to be taken or envisaged to implement the Convention. Finally, the project will continue to build institutional capacity for implementing the Convention in Albania including undertaking activities related to climate change education and awareness.

actual.comment: The national circumstances are completed; the GHG inventories are completed; the V&A Assessment are more than 75% completed; the Mitigation Analysis are more than 75% completed; Other Information is completed and Constraints and gaps analysis are more than 75% completed.

target.comment: to update the annual Albanian Inventory of Anthropogenic GHGs to the period 2000-2009, focusing on the sectors/gases that have a significant share of GHG emissions such as the transport sector; downscaled global models will be developed to regionalize climate projections and apply in Vulnerability and Adaptation assessments that are focused on the entire coastal region; state-of-the-art GHG mitigation modeling frameworks will be used to developed a national low carbon development strategy. Albania’s description of national circumstances will be updated, as well as the steps to be taken or envisaged to implement the Convention. Finally, the project will continue to build institutional capacity for implementing the Convention in Albania including undertaking activities related to climate change education and awareness.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description:
Improved EOD and quality management standards in line with the International Mine Action Standards.
A public awareness and risk education scheme running in the affected areas.
A victim assistance system in place to encompass all ERW/AXO survivors.

baseline.comment: The current government demilitarization plan is running solely as a military operation without considerations on safety measures and socio-economic impact on civilian population.

target.comment: Certification and handover of about 171,000 sqm of cleared UXO/ERW hotspots, in Gjeroven and Palikesht Berat, Suc in Diber and Pilur in Vlora. About 28,000 community members living around the highly contaminated hotspots are educated and aware about the ammunition threat. About 100 amputee survivors are fitted with either new prostheses or repairs and needs and status of at least 80% of ERW/AXO victims throughout Albania is documented. Albania’s Annual Transparency Reporting obligations to the international disarmament conventions are timely fulfilled.

actual.comment: Certification as free of unexploded ordnance from AMMCO of an area of 216,704 sqm in the following hotspots: Gjeroven, Palikesht, Suç and Pilur. More than 14,500 community members in the hotspot of Gjeroven, Palikesht, Suç,Pilur, Gerdec, Klos and Macukull benefited from Risk Education and Community Liaison activities. About 70 amputee survivors are fitted with prostheses or repairs. Five Annual Transparency Reports of the international disarmament conventions (CCW,CCM and APMBT) are timely fulfilled.

target.comment: Certification and handover of about 400,000 sqm of cleared UXO/ERW hotspots in Gjeroven, Palikesht and Mbreshtan in Berat, Klos and Suç in Diber, Gerdec and Laç. About 28,000 community members living around the highly contaminated hotspots are educated and aware about the ammunition threat. About 100 amputee survivors are fitted with either new prostheses or repairs and needs and status of at least 80% of ERW/AXO victims throughout Albania is documented. Albania’s Annual Transparency Reporting obligations to the international disarmament conventions are timely fulfilled.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Number of project supported beneficiaries in the ALMMs designed in the frame of the project. 2. 3 TEPs designed and implemented in the targeted regions 3. National framework for measuring CSR performance in the country is in place.

baseline.comment: 1. 47, 53 and 0 beneficiaries of ALMMs in Shkodra, Lezha and Kukes respectively 2. TEPs designed in 2011 in Kukes and Shkodra 3. No national system of monitoring CSR performance in the country

actual.comment: 1. 340 youth (69% female) have participated in the active labour market measures and following programme completion 80% remain employed in the private sector. 20 out of the 340 beneficiaries are youth with disabilities. 2. 17 TEP actions were implemented with the aim of generating / formalizing jobs in the targeted regions. 444 youth benefited directly from the interventions, 442 were trained, 80 employed, 166 self-employed. An additional 3000 benefited in-directly. 3. Transparent application and evaluation procedures were adopted by the National Employment Service for the allocation of government funded active labour market measures. This resulted in a 5 fold increase in the number of ALMM applications country-wide. 4. A national CSR performance measurement system is in place and was adopted by the Ministry of Economic Development, Trade and Entrepreneurship in the preparation of the first Annual CSR report in the country.

target.comment: Feasibility study on up-grading tourism related services and generating employment opportunities in Vlora-Saranda coastal stretch carried out.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: Reduced and amalgamated LGUs, able to provide efficent local services to citizens

baseline.comment: The country territorial set up/division with 373 local government s units hinder efficiency of governance and service provision.

target.comment: Formulation of new territorial division scenarios with participation of interested stakeholders and approval by the Parliament of the new Law on territorial division

actual.comment: - A thorough analyses of the social and economic situation of LGUs in the country is done - 5 scenarioes were developed based on the analyses and the set criteria - a national wide awareness compaign on the importance of territorial and administrative reform was accomplished - the law on territorial reform and division in 61 LGUs approved in the parliament

target.comment: - Establishment and capacity building of 61 groups at newly established LGUs level - Assessment/ due diligence of newly established local government units - Guidelines on amalgamation are developed - Profiles of newly established LGUs are designed reflecting changes in the territory. - financial consolidation of 61 LGUs - documentation management of the 61 amalgamated LGUs

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. New Social Protection and Inclusion Strategy, and M&E Frameworks developed in a participatory way 2. Number of new laws and secondary legislation supported to ensure conformity with the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. 3. Number of municipalities planning, budgeting and providing gender sensitive social services to most at risk populations 4. Number of policies and plans on social services developed or improved with participation of Civil Society Organizations and marginalized groups 5. Number of regional coordination committees established for participatory social impact assessment 6. Criteria and guidelines in place for adapting social and public services to the specific needs of Roma/Egyptian populations

baseline.comment: 1. National social protection and social inclusion strategies due to expire in 2013 2. No laws and secondary legislation in place; concept of accessibility not understood as a cross-cutting issue 3. Number of Local Government units with inclusive social policy services in place is not known 4. No regional coordination committees for participatory social impact assessment 5, No Criteria and guidelines in place for adapting social services to the specific needs of Roma/Egyptian populations

target.comment: 1. Data on socially excluded groups elaborated and dis-aggregated by all possible categories of vulnerability (roma and PWD) 2. Draft strategy SI (skeleton of the strategy elaborated) 3. Law on Inclusion of and Accessibility for persons with Disabilities approved 4. Two by- laws for PWD approved 5. At least one action plan for PWD developed and approved

actual.comment: 1. Draft vision, goal and objectives of the Policy Document on SI developed and agreed with key stakeholders 2. A document outlining the road map with detailed actions to be followed for the finalization of the SI strategy document and its action is developed 3. Law on Inclusion of and Accessibility for persons with Disabilities approved 4. The Review of the Disability Assessment System in Albania is carried out 5. Capacity building support interventions for government institutions at local level to design local plans for persons with disabilities as enshrined in the CRPD. 1 action plan for PWD developed and approved by Municipality council 6. Secondary analysis of the 2011 Census re. PwD and Roma outlining the level of functioning and their socio economic indicators 7. A Social Housing situation analysis and needs assessment is completed 8. Access to civil rights for marginalized communities through legal and paralegal services supported in Berat and Korca municipalities. 111 civil registration cases supported

target.comment: 1. Social Inclusion Policy Document 2015-2020 (including Indicators, Baselines and Targets for Social Inclusion Policies 2014-2020) finalized and endorsed by the government 2. Social exclusion profiles and policies for PWD and Roma developed, 3. By-laws of the law on Inclusion of and Accessibility for Persons with Disabilities elaborated through consultative process 4. Social Housing Strategy/ action plan (from social inclusion perspective) developed and endorsed by the government. A set of appropriate tools for the implementation and monitoring is in place 5. At least 2 demonstrative projects developed and implemented to accommodate the needs of persons with disabilities for education and integration

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: Electoral contestants rarely use available dispute resolution mechanisms due to a purported lack of confidence in the legal system and a culture of opting for political deals.

baseline.comment: Effective electoral management and legal remedy due processes to administrate and resolve election-related grievances are not adequately guaranteed nor provided to electoral stakeholders.

target.comment: A comprehensive analysis of voter education needs A new system for the registration of political parties and candidates A two-day BRIDGE module on Gender and Elections A four-day BRIDGE module on Electoral Dispute Resolution A training video on major aspects of the preparation for voting and the Voting Center, and Election Day duties An animated video for international election observers A software module for managing election logistics at the level of Voting Center

actual.comment: -A comprehensive analysis of voter education needs was undertaken through a serious of focus groups taking place in different regions of the country. These discussions centered on voters’ perception of the elections in the context of Albania’s new municipalities and how this affects voters’ need for information and motivations for participation. The results of this analysis have been provided to more than 2000 local NGOs and other organizations and institutions in Albania. -A new system for the registration of political parties and candidates has been developed and delivered to the CEC. A feature of this system is an interactive map of Albania that presents to voters a visualization of the new municipalities and the candidates standing for Mayor and Municipal Council. -A two-day BRIDGE module on Gender and Elections was provided to the CEC staff, civil society and international organizations. The workshop sought to explore issues facing women in elections in Albania, from the perspectives of voters, candidates and members of the election administration. The workshop identified priority areas for the CEC and other institutions to focus their collective efforts in the post-election period. -A four-day training on BRIDGE module on Election Dispute Resolution Training was organized for judges appointed as members of the Electoral College and CEC commissioners and staff on interpreting the Electoral Code and resolving electoral disputes. The training was co-organized with UN Women and based on Building Resources in Democracy, Governance and Elections (BRIDGE) methodology, combined with a series of case studies and simulations. The training program covered issues related to Voting Center fraud and irregularities, investigation techniques and evidentiary standards, allocation of mandates, and case management within and between the institutions. -A sixty-minute animated training video was created in cooperation with the CEC Election Commission department for members of th

baseline.comment: 1. 7 employment promotion measures currently implemented by NES; however, no operational plan in place. 2. No self-employment measure in place. 3. target.comment: 1. Operational plan of employment promotion measures developed and at least 2 new measures designed 2. Self-employment programme designed 3. Feasibility study on work-based learning models carried out 4. Models of quality assurance assessed and discussions on an Albanian model of quality assurance commence among relevant actors. 5. National list of occupations updated and occupational descriptions developed for all occupational levels.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: Online interface upgraded Automated reports production enabled Surveys on relevance of the portal carried out % of citizens entrusting the relevance of the portal increased 35 designated officials trained on relevant legislation, procedures and management of cases

baseline.comment: In February 2015, the Government launched a first of its kind anti-corruption portal. The portal is a novelty in Albania, a unique interface where citizens can report cases of corruption occurring across public institutions. This new initiative merges into one central website the former 22 websites of different institutions and agencies and provides for a “user friendly” way to denounce corruptive practices. A mid-term plan is to have a unique green line for the same purpose.

target.comment: The SW / Database Information System is enhanced/developed and functioning by end August 2015. All templates of formats for the periodic reporting developed by end August 2015. Survey on public perceived relevance of the A/C portal carried out in May and November 2015 SW/HW capacities further developed. The staff of the on-line Portal Supporting Unit has completed the trainings on the use of SW application by end July 2015. Designated officials trained on relevant legislation, procedures and management of denounced cases, monitoring and reporting by end September 2015 A manual of operations for the use of SW/Database application developed by end August 2015.

iati-activity.title: Flood Protection
iati-activity.description: The overall objective is to strengthen resilience and disaster risk preparedness and prevention in southeast Albania in line with the post-disaster needs assessment following the February 2015 floods.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: No. flood protection built environment restored in priority areas No. studies on disaster social impact and risk scenarios for building national and local capacities to address social and gender-based vulnerabilities and mitigate environmental and economic losses. No. flood protection built environment rehabilitated and put back to operation Assessment of impact of floods on vulnerable groups and their views on ways to cope with such risks. No. studies/reports carried out No. workshops and participants No. infrastructures rehabilitated Study on floods social impact Awareness raising targeting local authorities Vulnerability to climate change and other major disasters assessed for specified vulnerable groups, including gender considerations

baseline.comment: Obsolete, poorly maintained and damaged flood protection infrastructures Lack of technical studies and thus preparedness to cope with future risks and integrate such considerations into development agendas. Key flood protection infrastructures damaged, exposing about 26,000 ha of agricultural land at risk for next rainy season. PDNA 2015 No prior social assessment on floods impact with such a disaggregation detail; no inputs to local decision making from this angle.

target.comment: 17 prioritized as most urgent interventions to be completed possibly prior to the next rainy season. Four technical reports / assessments on social vulnerabilities and Disaster risk scenarios developed One assessment report on social impact of floods focusing on four municipalities
